questions.question_text: Outline what is meant by direct access as a method of file access.
Explain how direct access is used to locate a specific record in sequential files.
Explain how direct access is used to locate a specific record in random files.
Explain what is meant by the term non-composite data type and give an example of a non-composite data type.

Write pseudocode statements to declare the set data type EvenNumbers to hold this set of even numbers between 2 and 12:
2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12
Describe the effect of changing the allocation of bits used for the mantissa and for the exponent in a floating-point number with a fixed total number of bits.

Real numbers are stored in a computer, using floating-point representation with:
• 12 bits for the mantissa
• 4 bits for the exponent
• two’s complement form for both the mantissa and exponent.

Calculate the normalised floating-point representation of +54.8125 in this system.

Show your working.
Describe the sequential method of file access.
Explain how the sequential method of file access is applied to files with serial organisation and to files with sequential organisation.
Explain what is meant by non-composite and composite data types.

Write pseudocode statements to declare the record data type FootballClub to hold data about football clubs in a league, including:
• name of team
• date team joined the league
• main telephone number
• name of the manager
• number of members
• current position in the league.

Calculate the denary value of the given normalised floating-point number using:
• 10-bit mantissa
• 6-bit exponent
• two’s complement for both mantissa and exponent.

Mantissa: 0010011110
Exponent: 001000
Show your working.

Calculate the normalised floating-point representation of –102.75 using:
• 10-bit mantissa
• 6-bit exponent
• two’s complement for both mantissa and exponent.
Show your working.
Outline what is meant by the term collision in the context of adding a record to a random file.
Explain how a collision can be dealt with when writing records to a random file.
Complete the table to show the remaining hash values when using the modulus 3 function.
Describe what happens when the calculated hash value is a duplicate of a previously calculated hash value for a different record key.
Compare sequential and serial methods of file organisation.
State the most suitable method of file access when a record is referenced by a unique address on a disk-type storage medium.
State the most suitable method of file access when a bank stores its data records in ascending order of account number.
Write pseudocode to create an enumerated type called Parts to include these parts sold in a computer shop: Monitor, CPU, SSD, HDD, LaserPrinter, Keyboard, Mouse.
Write pseudocode to create a pointer type called SelectParts that will reference the memory location in which the current part name is stored.
Write the normalised floating-point representation of the following unsigned binary number using this system: 1011100.011001
State the consequence of storing the binary number in part (a)(i) as a floating-point number in this system. Justify your answer.
Describe the purpose of a user-defined data type.
(i) Define, using pseudocode, the enumerated data type SchoolDay. (ii) Define WeekEnd to hold data about non-school days.
Define, using pseudocode, the composite data type ClubMeet to hold data about club members.
Calculate the normalised floating-point representation of -7.25 in this system. Show your working.
Calculate the denary value of the given binary floating-point number. Show your working.
Normalise the given floating-point number. Show your working.
(i) Explain why the denary number 513 cannot be stored accurately as a normalised floating-point number. (ii) Describe an alteration to store this number accurately.
Write pseudocode statements to declare the enumerated data type Aircraft to hold data about the types of aircraft used for a flight.
Write pseudocode statements to declare the composite data type Flight to hold data about flights to a specific destination.
(i) Write the pseudocode statement to set up a variable for one record of the composite data type Flight. (ii) Write pseudocode to store the details of the flight in the variable.
Write the largest positive two’s complement binary number that can be stored in this system.
Calculate the denary value of the given binary floating-point number. Show your working.
State when underflow occurs in a binary floating-point system.
State what is meant by the term enumerated data type.
State what is meant by the term pointer data type.
Write the pseudocode statement to define the data type Quarter1, to hold the names of the first three months of a year.
(i) Write the pseudocode statement to set up a variable for one record of the composite data type Pet. (ii) Write pseudocode to store the details of the pet in the variable.
Write the normalised floating-point representation of +202 in this system. Show your working.
Write the normalised floating-point representation of -202 in this system. Show your working.
(i) State why the number is not normalised. (ii) Write the normalised floating-point representation of the number.
Write pseudocode statements to assign 1067 to the BuildingID of BuildingRegister and 'house' to the BuildingGroup of BuildingRegister.

(i) Write the type declaration for BuildingType in pseudocode. (ii) Write the new declaration for BuildingGroup in pseudocode. (iii) Write the new pseudocode statement to assign house to BuildingGroup of BuildingRegister.
(i) Write the declaration in pseudocode for OwnerName as PRIVATE. (ii) Explain why the properties have been set to PRIVATE.
Write pseudocode statements to assign 'A Level Computer Science' to Title of LibraryBook and FALSE to Fiction of LibraryBook.

(i) The value for NumberOfCopies must be between 1 and 10 inclusive. Write the updated line of pseudocode. (ii) Each library record will include one or more accession numbers, write the extra line of pseudocode.
Explain what is meant by a user-defined composite data type. Include an example of another user-defined composite data type.
Write pseudocode statements to declare the composite data type, TAppointments, to hold data about patients for a dental clinic.
Complete the file handling pseudocode to read dental records stored in a random file using the user‑defined data type TAppointments and print the contents of the file, one record at a time.
Write the normalised floating‑point representation of the binary number 0101010.111 using a system with 10 bits for the mantissa and 6 bits for the exponent.
Describe the reason why the normalised form of the binary number 0101011.111001 cannot be represented accurately using this system.
Describe how records are organised and accessed in a sequential file.
Complete the table to show the remaining hash values when using the modulus 5 function.
Calculate the normalised floating-point representation of 113.75 and show how it would be represented in each of the two systems provided.
Explain the problem that occurred in part (a) when representing the number in system 2.
Describe what is meant by composite and non-composite data types.
Write the normalised floating-point representation of +65.25 in this system using 12 bits for the mantissa and 4 bits for the exponent.
Explain the problem that will occur in storing the normalised floating-point representation of +65.20 in this system.
Describe sequential and random methods of file organisation.
Outline the process of sequential access for serial and sequential files.
Describe what is meant by enumerated and pointer data types.
Complete the file handling pseudocode to find a customer account record in a random file and output it.
Define the term exception handling.
State two possible causes of an exception.
Write the normalised floating-point representation of –96.75 in a system with 10 bits for the mantissa and 6 bits for the exponent.
Explain why a binary representation is sometimes only an approximation to the real number it represents.
Outline why protocols are essential for communication between computers.
State the names of two different protocols associated with the sending and receiving of emails between computers.

Explain the meaning of the phrase:
BitTorrent protocol provides peer-to-peer file sharing.

Complete the diagram to show the correct order for the TCP/IP layers:
Transport, Application, Link, Internet
Describe the function of the Transport layer.
Outline one protocol that is associated with the Application layer.
Explain how packet switching is used to transfer messages across the internet.
Outline the function of a router in packet switching.
Give two benefits and two drawbacks of packet switching.
Explain why a protocol is used in communication between computers.
Complete the diagram for the TCP/IP protocol stack.
Describe the purpose of the IMAP protocol.
Outline the functions of the Transport and Internet layers of the TCP/IP protocol suite.
Identify two protocols used by the application layer of the TCP/IP protocol suite and describe the use of each protocol.
Identify two other layers of the TCP/IP protocol suite and describe the function of each layer.
Describe both methods of data transmission, circuit switching and packet switching. Include a different advantage and disadvantage for each method.
State two examples of where it would be appropriate to use packet switching.
Give four differences between circuit switching and packet switching.
State, with a reason, where it would be appropriate to use circuit switching.
Give two benefits and two drawbacks of circuit switching.
Draw one line to connect each protocol to its most appropriate use. Protocols: HTTP, BitTorrent, SMTP, IMAP.
Outline the purpose of the Link layer in the TCP/IP protocol suite.
Complete the following paragraph about a protocol suite, using words from the given list.
Complete the pseudocode to find an item in a 1D array Widgets of type STRING, using a linear search.
Compare the methods used by the linear and binary search algorithms to find an item in an array. Refer to Big O notation in your answer.
State a condition that must be true for an array to be searchable for a binary search.
Complete the given pseudocode to find an item in a 1D array Names of type STRING using a binary search.
Describe the performance of a binary search in relation to the number of data items in the array being searched. Refer to Big O notation in your answer.
Write additional clauses to represent that Anthony is a student who would like to study history and geography.
Using the variable X, what is the result returned by the goal: choice1(X, mathematics)?
Write a rule in logic programming that allows a student to choose a subject if it is not their first choice.
Write additional clauses to represent that Carlos is a person who enjoys the hobby of cycling but does not like music.
Using the variable P, what is the result returned by the goal: enjoys(P, climbing)?
Write a rule in logic programming that allows a person to enjoy a hobby if they do not dislike it.
Draw one line from each programming paradigm to its most appropriate description.
State the reasons for including exception handling routines when writing a program. Include an example of an exception in your answer.
State whether each variable is valid or invalid and give a reason for your choice in each case.
Complete the Backus‑Naur Form (BNF) for <word> and use this to complete the BNF for <variable>.
Draw a syntax diagram for a vehicle registration that begins with two letters and is followed by one, two, or three digits.
Describe what is meant by recursion.
Complete the trace table for the function Fib(5) which calculates and returns values in the Fibonacci sequence using recursion.
Complete this file-handling pseudocode to copy an active accounts text file to an archive accounts text file, replacing blank lines with 'Account not present'.
State whether each of the following passwords is valid or invalid and give a reason for your choice.
Complete the Backus-Naur Form (BNF) for the syntax diagrams shown.
Draw a syntax diagram for an identifier that begins with one or more letters, followed by zero digits or one digit or more digits.
Describe, with an example, what is meant by an exception.
Complete the file handling pseudocode to search for a customer record in a random file AccountRecord.dat.
Give appropriate type declaration statements for a data type to hold a set of prime numbers below 20.
Give appropriate type declaration statements for a data type to point to a day in the week, for example Monday.
State two features of RISC processors.
Outline the process of interrupt handling as it could be applied to RISC or CISC processors.
Explain how pipelining affects interrupt handling for RISC processors.
Tick one box in each row to show if the statement applies to RISC or CISC processors.
Describe the process of pipelining during the fetch-execute cycle in RISC processors.
Identify the three other categories of computer architecture besides SISD and describe each category.
Identify the three other categories of computer architecture besides SISD and describe each category.
Describe what is meant by RISC and CISC processors.
Identify two differences between RISC and CISC processors.
Describe the use of pipelining in Reduced Instruction Set Computers (RISC).
Complete the table to show how a program consisting of six instructions would be completed using pipelining.
Outline the characteristics of massively parallel computers.
Describe the features of SISD and MIMD computer architectures.
Describe the features of the SIMD and MISD computer architectures.

The diagram shows a logic circuit.

Complete the truth table for the given logic circuit.
Show your working.

Write the Boolean expression that corresponds to the logic circuit as a sum-of-products.
Z =

Complete the Karnaugh map (K-map) for this Boolean expression:
A–.B–.C– + A–.B.C– + A–.B.C + A.B–.C– + A.B.C– + A.B.C
Draw loop(s) around appropriate group(s) in the K-map to produce an optimal sum-of-products.
Write the Boolean expression from your answer to part c(ii) as a simplified sum-of-products.

Complete the truth table for the given logic circuit.
(Show your working.)
Write the Boolean expression that corresponds to the logic circuit as a sum-of-products.

Complete the Karnaugh map (K-map) for the Boolean expression:
A.B.C + A.B.C + A.B.C + A.B.C + A.B.C + A.B.C
Draw loop(s) around appropriate group(s) in the K-map to produce an optimal sum-of-products.
Write the Boolean expression from your answer to part (c)(ii) as a simplified sum-of-products.
Write the Boolean expression that corresponds to the given truth table as a sum-of-products.
Complete the Karnaugh map (K-map) for the given truth table.
Complete the truth table for the given logic circuit. Show your working.
State the name of the logic circuit.
Write the Boolean expressions for the two outputs Y and Z in the truth table as sum-of-products and state the purpose of each output.
Draw a logic circuit for an SR flip-flop and label the inputs.
State the purpose of a flip-flop.
Simplify the expression using Boolean algebra, including De Morgan’s laws.
Complete the Karnaugh map (K-map) for the Boolean expression: Z = Ā. B. C̄. D̄ + Ā. B. C̄. D + A. B. C̄. D̄ + A. B. C̄. D + A. B̄. C̄. D̄ + A. B̄. C̄. D.
Draw loop(s) around appropriate group(s) in the K-map to produce an optimal sum-of-products.
Write the Boolean expression from your answer to part (b) as a simplified sum-of-products.
Complete the truth table for this logic circuit with two inputs and two outputs.
(i) State the name of this logic circuit. (ii) State the purpose of each output E and F.
Write the Boolean logic expression that corresponds to the given truth table as the sum‑of‑products.
Complete the Karnaugh map (K‑map) for the given truth table.
Draw loop(s) around appropriate group(s) in the K‑map to produce an optimal sum‑of‑products.
Write the Boolean logic expression from your answer to part (c) as a simplified sum‑of‑products.
Use Boolean algebra to give your answer to part (d) in its simplest form.
Complete the Karnaugh map (K-map) for the given Boolean expression.
Draw loop(s) around appropriate group(s) in the K-map to produce an optimal sum-of-products.
Write the Boolean logic expression from your answer to part (b) as a simplified sum-of-products.
Use Boolean algebra to give your answer to part (c) in its simplest form.
Complete the truth table for the given logic circuit.
Simplify the given Boolean expression using Boolean algebra.
Complete the truth table for the given logic circuit representing the Boolean expression X = A + B + C.
Apply De Morgan’s laws to the expression X = A + B + C.
Simplify the Boolean expression T = X.Y.Z + X.Y.Z + X using Boolean algebra.
Outline two benefits and two limitations of a virtual machine.
Explain the roles of the host operating system and the guest operating system as used in a computer system running a virtual machine.

Write this infix expression in Reverse Polish Notation (RPN):

(7 – 2 + 8) / (9 – 5)

Evaluate this RPN expression:

a d + a b + c - *

when
a = 6, b = 3, c = 7 and d = 9

Show the changing contents of the stack as the RPN expression is evaluated.

Write this RPN expression in infix form:

b a c - + d b + * c /

Write this Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) expression in infix form:
5 2 + 9 3 - / 3 *

Write this infix expression in RPN:
((7 + 3) - (2 * 8)) / 6

Evaluate this RPN expression:
a b - c d + * e /
when a = 17, b = 5, c = 7, d = 3, e = 10.
Show the changing contents of the stack as the RPN expression is evaluated.
Write the infix expression for the given Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) expression: 5 2 – 5 4 + * 9 /.
Explain how a stack can be used to evaluate RPN expressions.
Show the changing contents of the stack as the Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) expression 'a b * 2 / c d / *' is evaluated where a = 20, b = 3, c = 10, and d = 5.
Explain how an expression stored in RPN can be evaluated.
Write the Backus-Naur Form (BNF) notation of the syntax diagram for character.
Write the BNF notation of the syntax diagram for a valid password.
(i) Explain why Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is used to carry out the evaluation of expressions. (ii) Identify a data structure to evaluate an expression in RPN.
Write the infix expression in RPN: (a - b) * (a + c) / 7.
Write the RPN expression as an infix expression: a b / 4 * a b + -.
Evaluate the RPN expression: a b + c d / /, where a = 17, b = 3, c = 48, and d = 12. Show your working.
Draw one line to connect each Operating System (OS) term to the most appropriate description.
Explain how an interpreter executes a program without producing a complete translated version.
Explain the need for scheduling in process management.
Describe these scheduling routines and identify a benefit for each one: Shortest job first, Round robin, First come first served.
Describe what is meant by a virtual machine. Include in your answer two benefits and two drawbacks of using a virtual machine.
Identify two other stages that take place during the compilation of a program.
Outline the purpose of syntax analysis.
Explain what is meant by virtual memory.
State one difference between paging and segmentation in the way memory is divided.
Write the infix expression in Reverse Polish Notation (RPN): a * b + b - d + 15.
(i) Write the RPN expression in infix form: a b - c d + * a /. (ii) Evaluate your infix expression when a = 5, b = 10, c = 27, d = 12.
Draw one line to connect each stage of compilation to its most appropriate description.
The following assignment statements are invalid. State the reason in each case: (i) X1 = Y2 – 12, (ii) Z = Y12 + Z1.
Complete the Backus-Naur Form (BNF) for the syntax diagrams shown.
(i) Draw a syntax diagram for the new syntax of the assignment statement. (ii) Write the Backus-Naur Form (BNF) for your syntax diagram.
Describe two benefits and one limitation of using a virtual machine.
Write the Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) for the expression: (j + k)/(j - k).
(i) Show the changing contents of the stack as the value for p is calculated from its RPN expression. (ii) Describe the main steps in the evaluation of this RPN expression using a stack.
State two other uses of a stack.
State one benefit to the student of a user interface and give an example.
Identify one other process state besides running and ready.
Outline conditions under which a process could change from the running state to the ready state.
Outline the reasons why an operating system may need to use virtual memory.
Explain the circumstances in which disk thrashing could occur.
Explain what is meant by Reinforcement Learning in relation to Artificial Intelligence.
Explain what is meant by Deep Learning in relation to Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Calculate the shortest distance between the Start and each of the destinations in the diagram using Dijkstra’s algorithm.
State the reason for having multiple hidden layers in an artificial neural network.
Explain how artificial neural networks enable machine learning.
Calculate the shortest distance between the base and each of the other towns using Dijkstra’s algorithm. Show your working and write your answers in the table provided.
Explain the use of graphs to aid Artificial Intelligence (AI).
Describe supervised learning and unsupervised learning.
Describe what is meant by deep learning.
Outline the reasons for using deep learning.
State one category of machine learning.
Calculate the path that takes the shortest time to travel from the Begin node to the End node, using the A* algorithm.
Explain what is meant by the term artificial neural network.
Draw one line from each machine learning category to its most appropriate description.
Describe the purpose of both the A* algorithm and Dijkstra’s algorithm.
Define these Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) terms: Encapsulation, Getter, Setter.
Complete the diagram for the object SubstituteTeacher, including appropriate properties and their getters and setters.
Define these Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) terms: Instance, Inheritance, Polymorphism.

Complete the pseudocode for the class Car to enable objects to be created. The class needs to include string attributes to store the make, model, body type, and fuel type, and an integer attribute to store the number of cars of that type built.
Complete this class inheritance diagram to show the properties, methods and inheritance for Yarn, Acrylic, Wool, and Mix.
Describe what is meant by the terms properties, methods and inheritance.
Draw one line from each Object‑Oriented Programming (OOP) term to its most appropriate description.

Sheila has a customer called Fred. Fred wants to send Sheila a confidential document as part of a transaction.

Explain how Fred uses asymmetric encryption to send his document securely.
Describe what is meant by a digital certificate.
Explain the role of a digital certificate in creating a digital signature.
Describe the purpose of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocols.
Explain how SSL/TLS protocols are used when a client-server communication is initiated.
State two differences between symmetric and asymmetric encryption.
Explain the process by which an organisation may acquire its digital certificate.
State what is meant by a private key.
Describe the process of asymmetric encryption.
Explain how a digital signature is used to verify a message when it is received.
State how a digital certificate is obtained.
(i) Explain how a digital signature is produced before the message is sent. (ii) Explain how the digital signature can be checked on receipt.
(i) Give two reasons for using key cryptography. (ii) Give two methods of key cryptography that can be used.
(i) State two possible benefits of using quantum cryptography. (ii) State two possible drawbacks of using quantum cryptography.
Describe the purpose of quantum cryptography.
Explain the differences between symmetric and asymmetric cryptography when encrypting and decrypting data.
Describe the purpose of asymmetric key cryptography.
Identify two benefits and two drawbacks of quantum cryptography.
State the addressing mode and the contents of ACC after each instruction has been executed.
Use only the given instruction set to write assembly language code to add the constant 20 to the value stored in the address contained in variable Y and store the result in variable Z.

Jane is a client who would like to choose the activity surfing and she has already done sailing.
Write additional clauses to represent this information.

Using the variable List, the goal:
choice(List, rowing)
returns List = petra, eliza

Write the result returned by the goal:
choice(List, sailing)

C is a client who would like to choose A if A is an activity and C has not already done A.
Write this as a rule: may_choose_activity(C, A)

Sliding doors is a feature that is available on a minivan but unavailable on a hatchback.
Write additional clauses to represent this information.

Write the result returned by the goal:
available(Options, hatchback)

F may be available for B if F is a feature and B is a body style and F is not unavailable for that body style.
Write this as a rule:
may_choose_option(F, B)
Complete the table of identifiers by writing the missing data types and descriptions for implementing a stack Abstract Data Type (ADT) using pseudocode.
Complete the pseudocode for the procedures to initialise a stack and push new items onto it.
Justify the use of a linked list instead of an array to implement a stack.
Explain how a compiler makes use of a stack when translating recursive programming code.
Write the pseudocode for the required declarations to set up a stack.
Complete the pseudocode function Pop() to pop an item from the stack.
Compare and contrast the queue and stack Abstract Data Types (ADT).
Write the pseudocode to declare MaxSize, FrontPointer, RearPointer, Length and Queue for a queue Abstract Data Type (ADT) with items of the string data type.
Complete the pseudocode for the function Dequeue to remove the front item from the queue.
Explain how a new element can be added to the queue if it is implemented using two stacks.
Insert the identifiers to complete the table for the queue ADT.
Complete the given pseudocode for the queue ADT.
Explain why a queue ADT works better than a stack ADT in organising print jobs.
Write additional clauses to record that Sam studies history and Nina is his tutor.
Write the result returned by the goal: studies(Student, geography).
Write the goal, using the variable X, to find all the students who have a tutor that teaches them.
Write additional clauses to record that a caracal is a wild cat with short hair.
Write the result returned by the goal: hair(Cat, long).
(i) Write the goal, using the variable Pet, to find all the domestic cats. (ii) Write the goal, using the variable WildSpotty, to find all the wild cats with spots.
State three essential features of recursion.
Explain the reasons why a stack is a suitable Abstract Data Type (ADT) to implement recursion.
Identify two ADTs other than a stack.
Complete the pseudocode for the function AddInteger() to add a new integer data element to a stack.
Describe what is meant by an imperative (procedural) programming language.
Describe what is meant by a declarative programming language.
Identify the programming paradigm for each of the program code examples provided.
State two factors that may affect the performance of a sorting algorithm.
Write an algorithm, using pseudocode, that will perform the same task using an insertion sort.
Complete the table to show the new values of HeadPointer and NextPointer to keep the remaining flower names in alphabetical order.
Complete the pseudocode algorithm for searching the linked list and finding a flower name.
Explain how you could improve the simplified linked list structure.
Complete this pseudocode binary search algorithm for an array of names in alphabetical order.
(i) State the Big O notation for time complexity of a linear search. (ii) Describe the meaning of O(log n) as it applies to a binary search algorithm.
Complete the pseudocode algorithm for a linear search.
(i) State the necessary condition for a binary search. (ii) Describe how to perform a binary search.
(i) Explain how the performance of a binary search varies with the number of values in the array. (ii) Compare the performance of binary search and linear search using Big O notation.

Write program code for the procedure ReadWords() which:
• takes a file name as a parameter
• opens the file and reads in the data
• stores the main word in the first element in WordArray
• stores each answer in a new element in WordArray
• counts and stores the number of answers.

Write program code for the main program that:
• asks the user to enter "easy", "medium" or "hard"
• calls ReadWords() with the filename that matches the user’s input.

Write program code for the procedure Play() which:
• outputs the main word and number of answers
• allows the user to enter words until 'no' is typed
• outputs whether the input is a correct answer
• counts and nullifies correct answers in the array.

Amend Play() so that when the user stops:
• output the percentage of answers given correctly
• output all the answers the user did not enter.
Amend ReadWords() to call Play() after the data has been read.

Test your program with the inputs: easy, she, out, no.
Take a screenshot and paste it in the evidence document.

Test your program with the inputs: hard, fine, fined, idea, no.
Take a screenshot and paste it in the evidence document.
Write program code to declare the class Tree and its constructor. Do not declare the other methods. All attributes must be private. In Python, use comments to declare attributes.
Write program code for the get methods: GetTreeName(), GetGrowth(), GetMaxHeight(), GetMaxWidth(), GetEvergreen().

Write program code for the function ReadData():
- creates an array of Tree objects
- reads from Trees.txt
- raises exception if not found
- appends Tree objects to array
- returns array.

Write program code for PrintTrees(TreeObject):
- Outputs name, height growth, max height, max width, and evergreen status
- Formats message depending on whether it is evergreen.

Write program code for the main program:
- Calls ReadData()
- Calls PrintTrees() with first Tree object.
Test your program and take a screenshot of the output after calling ReadData() and PrintTrees().

Write program code for ChooseTree():
- Prompts user for max height, max width, and evergreen preference
- Filters tree list
- Calls PrintTrees() for each match
- Outputs message if none match.

Amend ChooseTree() to:
- Ask user for chosen tree name and initial height
- Calculate and output years to reach max height.

Amend the main program to call ChooseTree().
Test with: max height 400, max width 200, evergreen.
Choose: Blue Conifer, starting height 100 cm.
Take a screenshot of the output.
Write program code to declare the class TreasureChest. Do not write any other methods. The attributes are private.
Write program code for the procedure readData() to read data from TreasureChestData.txt, create objects, and append them to arrayTreasure. Use exception handling for file errors.
Write the method getQuestion() in the TreasureChest class that returns the question.
Write the method checkAnswer() in the TreasureChest class. It takes a parameter and returns True if the answer is correct, otherwise False.
Write the method getPoints() in the TreasureChest class. It takes the number of attempts as a parameter and returns points based on the number of attempts.
Write program code for the main program that calls readData(), requests a question number from the user, and handles output, answer checking, and scoring.

Test the program: select question 1 and answer it correctly on the first attempt; select question 5 and answer it correctly on the second attempt. Take screenshots showing input(s) and output(s) for each test.
Write program code to declare the class Character and its constructor. Do not write program code for the other methods.
Write program code for the three get methods for the class Character.
Write program code for the method ChangePosition().
Amend the main program by writing program code to declare the array, read in all 10 characters from Characters.txt, and store each character as an object in the array.
Amend the main program to read in a character’s name from the user, search for the character in the array, and store the index of its position, repeating until the name exists in the array.
Amend the main program to take a letter as input until it is a valid move (A, W, S, or D), changing the position of the character based on the direction.
Amend the main program to output the character’s name and new x and y coordinates after the position change.
Test your program by inputting the specified data sequence and take a screenshot of the output.
Write program code to declare a global 1D array, DataArray, with space for 100 integer values.

The procedure ReadFile() must read in the numbers from the text file and store each one in the array. Use appropriate exception handling.
Write program code for the procedure ReadFile().
